brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine the diagnostic and management concordance of
      face-to-face dermatologist versus a store-and-forward teledermatologist at a skin cancer
      screening event.

      The investigators' hypotheses include the following:

        1. Compared to in-person assessment, store-and-forward teledermatology assessment will
           result in adequate diagnostic concordance.

        2. Compared to in-person assessment, store-and-forward teledermatology results in adequate
           management concordance.

        3. The sensitivity and specificity of store-and-forward evaluation to detecting lesions
           that are either premalignant or malignant will be similar to that of in-person
           evaluation.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Store-and-Forward Teledermatology Versus a Face-to-Face Assessment During a Skin Cancer Screening Event

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  18 years of age or older at time of consent, may be male or female.

          -  Able to provide a brief medical history and have/allow an examination of their skin
             including photographs.

          -  Capable of giving informed consent.

          -  Will be able to receive notification of follow-up recommendations

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients who will not provide informed consent

          -  Patient who are unable to fulfill tasks of this study

intervention.description: Every patient will be evaluated by an in person dermatologist present at the screening.
Every patient will be evaluated online via a store and forward teledermatology modality.

facility.name: University of California, Davis Shifa Community Clinic

clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Store-and-Forward Teledermatology Versus a Face-to-Face Assessment During a Skin Cancer Screening Event

primary_outcome.description: Aggregated diagnostic concordance which is defined as the agreement of the in-person dermatologist's principle diagnosis with the teledermatologist's primary diagnosis or any of the differential diagnoses.
primary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of dermatologist evaluation (Day 1)

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Asst Prof of Dermatology, Director of Clinical Research Unit

secondary_outcome.description: Diagnostic concordance between the in-person dermatologist and the teledermatologist for their primary diagnosis.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of dermatologist evaluation (Day 1)

secondary_outcome.description: Diagnostic concordance between the in-person dermatologist and teledermatologist based on standard clinical diagnostic categories for each lesion.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of dermatologist evaluation (Day 1)

secondary_outcome.description: The concordance between the in-person dermatologist and teledermatologist for the chosen management plan for each lesion.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of dermatologist evaluation (Day 1)

secondary_outcome.description: The sensitivity of store-and-forward evaluation to detecting lesions that are either premalignant or malignant.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of dermatologist evaluation (Day 1)

secondary_outcome.description: The specificity of store-and-forward evaluation to detecting lesions that are either premalignant or malignant.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of dermatologist evaluation (Day 1)

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Non-Randomized, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Screening
